page.title: 01THE AREA SOUTH OF NEWCHURCH
page.content: Newchurch, a marshland area, is flat with no land rising above zero feet, in fact the surface is some 12' below mean high tide. It is crossed by drainage ditches known locally as dykes which flow north into The Royal Military Canal and south into The Clobsden Sener providing ample open water for the local retained fire brigade. All roads are of B class. Low density population makes this a quiet place with abundant wildlife including Swans, Magpies, Starlings, Herons and rare birds. Also butterflies, the Common Blue, Meadow Brown, Cabbage White. People are a mixture of professionals working in nearby towns and working class who work on the farms and in the chemical world, chafers. Land use is a mixture of intensive crops, peas, beans, wheat and rape and grazing of the local
